content:
Both American Airlines and British Airways are excellent choices for flying to London. Here's a comparison of their in-flight entertainment systems and seat comfort to help you make an informed decision:

**In-Flight Entertainment:**

**American Airlines:**

* **System:** AA's in-flight entertainment system is called "AA Inflight Entertainment" and offers a wide selection of movies, TV shows, music, and games.
* **Screens:** Seat-back screens are available on most aircraft, with some planes featuring larger screens (up to 15.4 inches) on international flights.
* **Content:** Over 300 movies, 200 TV shows, 30 albums, and 100 games are available, including new releases and classic titles.
* **Personal Device Entertainment:** You can also stream content to your personal device using the American Airlines app (free on domestic flights, paid on international flights).

**British Airways:**

* **System:** BA's in-flight entertainment system is called "High Life Entertainment" and offers a vast library of content.
* **Screens:** Seat-back screens are available on all long-haul aircraft, with some planes featuring larger screens (up to 18.5 inches) in premium cabins.
* **Content:** Over 1,000 hours of entertainment are available, including the latest movies, TV shows, music, and games.
* **Personal Device Entertainment:** You can also stream content to your personal device using the British Airways app (free on all flights).

**Seat Comfort:**

**American Airlines:**

* **Economy Class:** Seats on AA's Boeing 777-300ER and 787-9 aircraft feature a pitch of 31-32 inches and width of 17.2-17.5 inches. Seats on other aircraft may have slightly less legroom.
* **Premium Economy:** Seats on AA's 777-300ER and 787-9 aircraft offer more legroom (38 inches) and width (19 inches).
* **Business Class:** Lie-flat beds with a pitch of 77 inches and width of 20.5 inches are available on some aircraft.

**British Airways:**

* **Economy Class:** Seats on BA's Boeing 777-300ER and Airbus A350-1000 aircraft feature a pitch of 31-32 inches and width of 17.5-18 inches. Seats on other aircraft may have slightly less legroom.
* **Premium Economy:** Seats on BA's 777-300ER and A350-1000 aircraft offer more legroom (38 inches) and width (18.5 inches).
* **Business Class:** Lie-flat beds with a pitch of 79 inches and width of 20 inches are available on some aircraft.

**Other Considerations:**

* **Food and Drink:** Both airlines offer a range of meal options, but British Airways is known for its more extensive menu and higher-quality food.
* **Service:** Both airlines are known for their friendly and attentive service, but some passengers prefer the more formal, traditional service style of British Airways.

Ultimately, the choice between American Airlines and British Airways depends on your personal preferences and priorities. If you value a wider selection of in-flight entertainment and more legroom in economy class, British Airways might be the better choice. If you prefer a more extensive menu and a more formal service style, British Airways might be the way to go. If you're looking for a more modern aircraft with larger screens and a more streamlined entertainment system, American Airlines might be the better option.
